Previously, GrayHatter (Gregory Mullen) wrote… > We could always hook this into the do_NAT function. > > Other than that, I think an hour is a good choice for now. We can always revise it later. >
> Having the port forwarded only for 1 hour is a bad choice, users might run Tox for longer than 1 hour. Having the port forwarded for a week is also a bad choice, users might run Tox for less than a week, and leaving port forwarded is a bad idea security-wise (though if we could UPNP a port, a malicious application probably could too, so that's an arguable statement). Ideally the port should be forwarded for as long as Tox runs, no more, no less. To do this, we will need to hook up NAT traversal into `tox_iterate()` loop. It will request the port forwarding for a small time, maybe a minute, and every iteration of `tox_iterate()` it will check if the port forwarding is about to expire, and if so, extend it by a minute again. Hooking it up into `tox_iterate()` might also help with removing the `sleep()` below, though I believe we need to sleep initially, when there is no port forwarding set up yet (we need to block the networking code from executing until ports are forwarded), but after that, when we will be extending it, we could not `sleep()` but just check it every `tox_iterate()` if we have received a reply for the outstanding request. --- _[toxcore/nat_traversal.c, line 183 at r11](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/226#-KWSIrRyxRPZNxfVjQ7F:-KWbKLKnZlWByZxEiQFR:b39m1yb) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/5f464419c560b232922bae7f91b0de27cadec028/toxcore/nat_traversal.c#L183)):_

_[toxcore/nat_traversal.c, line 207 at r14](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/226#-KX-tUdFqaabsdoO7lHm:-KX-tUdFqaabsdoO7lHn:bsjwp1y) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/9823dc5c34a7a4347fb9387140384c86ed3b85cf/toxcore/nat_traversal.c#L207)):_

> ``` C
> 
> /* Setup port forwarding */
> bool nat_map_port(Logger *log, uint8_t traversal_type, NAT_TRAVERSAL_PROTO proto, uint16_t port, bool ipv6_enabled,
> ```

`nat_map_port()` with `ipv6_enabled=true` will call `upnp_map_port()` for ipv6 and `natpmp_map_port()` for ipv4.

`nat_map_port()` with `ipv6_enabled=false` will call `upnp_map_port()` for ipv4 and `natpmp_map_port()` for ipv4.

This is a weird behavior.  In toxcore `ipv6_enabled` means "try both ipv4 and ipv6", so I'd expect:

`nat_map_port()` with `ipv6_enabled=true` will call `upnp_map_port()` for ipv6 and ipv4 and `natpmp_map_port()` for ipv4.

`nat_map_port()` with `ipv6_enabled=false` will call `upnp_map_port()` for ipv4 and `natpmp_map_port()` for ipv4.

This also means that would need to call `nat_map_port()` just once for `ipv6_enabled=true`.

@Ansa89 would it make sense to do the NAT traversal in tox_iterate, and integrate it into that loop, so we can re-bind the port when the router loses it (reboot/timeout/bugs)? This would be a bit of refactoring here, so perhaps it would make sense to merge this code provided we have a commitment to finishing the refactoring.

I was thinking about that last week. It would be a nice thing to keep the port bound directly inside `tox_iterate()`, but there is a problem: `tox_iterate()` is executed every `tox_iteration_interval()` ms and I guess it's a value "< 1s"; IMHO it's not a good idea to spam the router with bind-requests so frequently when we can request a bind for 300s (or any other value that makes sense for you) and re-bind after that amount of time.
Moreover the binding process has sleep/wait timeouts which you probably don't want inside `tox_iterate()`.

The binding process should not have sleeps in it. Instead, you use the time passing outside (in the client iterate loop) as waiting time.
I can't merge this as is, because it makes tox_new take several seconds.

The natpmp one works fine without threads, right? Perhaps you can make this work for just natpmp, and remove the upnp support for now. That way, we can merge it, and have some form of nat traversal support (and an API for it). We can then later look into making upnp work for us.

I can remove upnp (actually I would prefer to force-disable it at compile time, keeping the code here), but consider that natpmp is mainly used on apple hardware for what I can understand and I don't know if there are routers that implement that protocol (except apple ones).
Also looking other projects, I don't think there are alternatives to bypass upnp timeouts (using miniupnpc).

Looking for other protocols, I found ICE (using pjproject), but that needs some discussion before trying to implement it.
